summary: Traveling back in time isn't simple, as James Cole (Bruce Willis) learns the hard way. Imprisoned in the 2030s, James is recruited for a mission that will send him back to the 1990s. Once there, he's supposed to gather information about a nascent plague that's about to exterminate the vast majority of the world's population. But, aside from the manic Jeffrey (Brad Pitt), he gets little in the way of cooperation, not least from medical gatekeepers like Dr. Kathryn Railly (Madeleine Stowe).

reviews.content: This is a strange film but it has an interesting plot that keeps you invested despite the goofy characters and sub-par acting from some of the lesser known cast. Bruce Willis gives a good performance but it is Brad Pitt that steals every scene he is in. The film feels a little dated but the futuristic settings and technology look very good and still hold up well. The ending is predictable and you can see the twists coming if you pay enough attention. If you're into 90's films or time-travel concepts then you should enjoy this.

Classic. Love love love. Brad Pitt is amazing. Clever story. Saw it in the theatre and just watched for the 10 or 15th time and it was the first time I looked up the ending explained; did not know that that's what she meant by ‘insurance.' 🤦🏻‍♀️

I really liked the acting (specifically mainly from Brad Pitt and at times Bruce Willis) and the premise was very interesting. At first I didn't quite get it but then I was hooked once I found out that Cole was traveling through time (which at first I didn't think would be overused). I really liked the scenes with Cole and Goines in the mental hospital and how certain things connected in the plot sequences, however at a certain point the movie slowed down for me and got a little too distracted by the time traveling angle and Cole's romance with the psychiatrist. It seemed to be building up to something that ultimately wasn't worth the payoff with a kind of ambiguous ending.

Although this film did have some stuff to enjoy in its premise and its themes, the actual nuts and bolts of the story and how it's told got on my nerves. Perhaps I got my hopes up too high or was hoping for something this film wasn't interested in providing, but this movie was just so much dumber than I expected. Basically every character acts like a complete idiot so when it tried to get me to empathize and care for the character's emotional journey I just didn't have it in me because I found everything they did to be so annoyingly dumb. 

Bruce Willis's character kept fluctuating between a somewhat normally intelligent guy and a complete caveman brain and his co-stars weren't much better. About halfway through I thought that this tone might've worked a lot better if this were a satire/comedy like Brazil but without any jokes or enough exaggeration in the world it didn't fit that either. 

I really was excited to watch this movie, and though I don't consider it bad per se, I am sadly quite disappointed after watching it.

Also it felt so predictable and rote that I successfully guessed the exact way it was going to end in the first minute.
Didn't understand the appeal when I was younger, don't understand the appeal now. Bleak, moronic.

Terry Gilliam was making this directly after The Fisher King and after abandoning A Tale of Two Cities. He was up on the sea of fates and had not entered the darkest phase of his career.

Executive producer Robert Kosberg was a fan of a French called La Jetée and convinced its director Chris Marker to let him try and get the movie made by Universal, who bought the rights and hired writers David and Janet Peoples. David was a writer on Blade Runner, Unforgiven, Ladyhawke, Soldier and wrote and directed The Blood of Heroes. Janet wrote several documentaries before collaborating with her husband on this script.

Producer Charles Roven felt that Gilliam was the perfect choice to direct this non-linear movie.

A deadly virus was released in 1996 by the Army of the Twelve Monkeys and now the survivors live underground. James Cole (Bruce Willis) is one of those survivors, a prisoner due to his violent outbursts and emotions, who is selected to go back in time and warn others in the past. He's also suffering from dreams of a shooting in an airport.

When he arrives in Baltimore, he's six years early and institutionalized, a prison all over again. Only Dr. Kathryn Railly (Madeleine Stowe) and another patient, the anti-capitalist Jeffrey Goines (Brad Pitt) listen to him. Cole tries to escape and ends up back in the future, where he's told that he must stop Goines, who seemingly is the one to unleash the virus. The time machine is faulty and sends him to World War I before its correct destination of 1996, a time when Railly is giving a speech about the Cassandra complex -- when a prophet warns others of danger and is not listened to -- and ends up meeting Dr. Peters (David Morse), who tells her that anyone who believes in the end of the world is sane and anyone who denies the ecological collapse of Earth is the one truly crazy.

Cole kidnaps Railly and they learn that Goines definitely is the founder of the Army of the Twelve Monkeys, using the virus that his father Dr. Leland Goines (Christopher Plummer) invented and inspired from meeting Cole in 1990. Yet is that true? Is Cole insane? Is the time travel actually happening? And what really is his mission?

Gilliam himself said that "The story is disconcerting. It deals with time, madness and a perception of what the world is or isn't. It is a study of madness and dreams, of death and re-birth, set in a world coming apart."

At one point, Cole goes from believer to unbeliever and Railly makes the opposite decision. In one of Marker's later films, Sans Soleil, a voiceover states "only one film has been capable of portraying impossible memory, insane memory: Alfred Hitchcock's Vertigo*." Cole and Railly watch this film within the movie -- Cole says, "I think I've seen this movie before" -- and we even hear the strings of Bernard Hermann's theme play.

This was probably a hard watch back in 1995 and today, it's really difficult. I mean, someone immolated themselves to draw attention to climate change yesterday. Wynn Bruce spent an entire year planning this action only for his death to be lost in the coverage of celebrity relationships.

The movie posits that 2035 is the darkest time of the future. Yet in 2030, if global emissions aren't halved, this world will be unlivable. But what can one person do -- like Cole, I feel I am not even a cog in this vast secret shadow machine -- when the majority of the damage is caused by corporations? And oh yeah, a movie about a pandemic when we're living in one that people want to be over and refer to this as post-COVID and people whip their masks off in joy on airplanes which already circulate air filled with illness.

This got dark quick, huh?

Cole says, "Maybe the human race deserves to be wiped out," but I'm still not so sure.

*Credit for this goes to this article on Little White Lies.
An incredibly imaginative, if very, very dark Masterpiece and one of the very few movies  with a single sentence punchline - "I'm in Insurance."

This is like a descendant of 'Cuckoo's Nest' except this take on the mental institution trope is a mildly thought-provoking conspiratorial thriller featuring a very dedicated Bruce Willis. A career highlight of his for sure.

"12 Monkeys" is a movie with lots of plot twists, but at the same time, with no plot twists. I'll not develop this argument deeper because this film doesn't allow spoilers, but if you watch, you'll understand my point and probably agree. Bruce Willis in the 90s was at the pinnacle of his career (when he was actually caring for it, he did exceptional movies, like "Pulp Fiction", "The Sixth Sense", "Unbreakable" and this one), Madeleine Stowe was nice but she, from nowhere, acquires Stockholm syndrome (my only issue with the film), and Brad Pitt give us the funniest and one of the best characters of his career (for which he deservedly received an Oscar nomination). Terry Gilliam is a comedy director (he directed Monty Python), and because of that, the film is hilarious and the comic timing is perfect. Finally, that music theme is one of the best I've ever heard. Not only because it's contagious, but also because it purposely seems to contradict the movie's tone.

Terry Gilliam's true masterpiece comes with the modern day sci fi classic in 12 Monkeys. In true Gilliam form we are served a whimsically wacky narrative with his aesthetic style written all over it. With this one you may have to hold on for dear life to understand, but unlocking the puzzle is part of the beauty of the film. Without question its a film that requires multiples viewings to fully grasp the unconventional visual display. Terry is a true visionary. Brad Pitt is exceptional here, one of the biggest Oscar snubs of all time. Bruce Willis is also fantastic & really channels some serious emotion matching well with Madeline Stowe who truly makes her on screen presence known in every scene.  

One thing we've learned in the past when speaking of time travel is that there is usually an inevitability that is impossible to avoid.
The first 55 minutes were weird and boring enough that I gave up on watching

It's one of Terry Gilliam's more easily digestible films, but still has his visual trademarks all over it. The plot is quite engaging and the actors are all doing solid work, with Brad Pitt being especially entertaining; seemingly replicating Dennis Hopper's character from Apocalypse Now. If you've never seen it, or hate time travel movies, just give it a shot. It's got enough personality to make up for any shortcomings.

good movie! i love Bruce Willis, but Bad Pitt stole the show for me. another pretty eccentric role - & he pulled it off brilliantly. i really loved the story & how everything came together... I've read a lot of reviews knocking the ending, but i actually really like how it ended. it's realistic, in a sci-fi time travel kind of way. you'll never alter the future because everything has already happened; you're already living in that alternate future you created because you went back in time. so now Cole's character is just stuck in an infinite loop of alternate realities that are all the same every time. it's beautifully tragic. would definitely recommend.
Watch it sober, and try to keep up because this loony trip will make you wonder what is real and what is insanity. A good film that is carried well by Willis and Pitt.

Fans of Terry Gillian or Steampunk will love the sleazy, sinister and sometimes very silly sets of 12 Monkeys. Those who know Bruce Willis's work as an anti-hero won't be disappointed either, as his performance is riveting. The opportunity to move beyond simple hero tropes was seized firmly by Willis, who holds our attention throughout, despite the script getting a tad confusing at times. Brad Pit is terrific too, though fans of his smooth, urbane persona might be shocked. A time-travel sci-fi with a downbeat ending, 12 Monkeys is a must for fans of the genre.

Kind of a letdown, after all the great reviews. A twisty time travel thing; actually  great concept. Willis, so perfect in "The Sixth Sense", and "Die Hard", doesn't quite know what to do with his character (I suspect director Terry Gilliam is to blame, not Willis).

I, too,  spent a lot of time wondering "what's happening?" -- and not in a good way. 

Newcomer Brad Pitt was rightly nominated for an Oscar for sheer frenetic fun, and Madeleine Stowe was fine, playing off the madness. It was depressing to see the venerable Christopher Plummer allowing himself to be demeaned in that scene in the van. Actors should maintain some dignity.

I was 16 in 1996 when this movie first came out. It was about a world where humans were massacred by a virus that same year. The movie haunted me. I distinctly remember hating it at first. Felt like a waste of time. I became obsessed because I knew there was something I missed. So I watched it again. Then I watched it again. Then it became my favorite movie. With each viewing, I discovered something new. 15 years later was the first time I caught the real ending that I never noticed before. 25 years later I am still amazed at all the little seeds planted throughout the film that you never notice until it haunts you into watching it again and again and again.

5 billion people die in 1997 from a deadly virus according to a Baltimore hospital and the animals will reign over earth. The remaining survivors will go underground.
Terry Gilliam directs a post apocalyptic flick starring Bruce Willis, Madeline Stowe, Christopher Plummer, and Brad Pitt.
Every human has to wear protective gear from head to toe even when going outside. 
James Cole is a prisoner but the higher power scientists give him a chance to reduce his sentence in order to give the human race a chance to go back above. Stowe is Kathryn Railly, a psychiatrist assigned to him. Cole is declared mentally unstable believing it's 1996 when's actually 1990. Turns out he was sent back from the future in the late 2030s. He's then put in an institution with a man named Jefferey played by Pitt. Jeffereys father is a renowned scientist played by Plummer specializing in experimenting on animals which displeases him. Before he was committed Jeffery decided to rebel and form an underground resistance called Twelve Monkeys. His own father may be the cause of all the suffering Cole is trying to prevent. Cole's mission is to gather intel about this deadly plague so he can save the human race later. Might have something to do with the Army of the Twelve Monkeys. Eventually Cole is sent to the right time and runs into Dr. Railly again, she's of course skeptical of his ramblings but realizes he might actually be truthful. 
It's true the past cannot be changed only the future. Maybe the only truth is mankind's insatiable appetite to destroy itself is the inevitable that cannot be avoided. Perhaps there is no escaping fate or destiny. Psychiatry is the latest religion, what experts say goes.
The possibilities of this movie coinciding with our current covid-19 situation is evident. It shares an Orwellian tone along the likes of a dystopian future in the movie Brazil. A society existing in a cold concrete world of minimalism and technology. Yes the time travel theory isn't perfect but it's possible.
The film acts more like a psychological-drama than a straight up apocalyptic action thriller. It's a sci-fi movie that preys on apocalyptic fears.
Cole keeps seeing visions of a shooting in public but is any of it real? His hope is to release humans from their underground dwellings much like animals in cages. 
Terry Gilliam juggles big ideas, time-travel paradoxes, breathless action, and inspired performances. He captures an unstable present that veers towards the inevitable. The filmmaking techniques are something to appreciate too full of Dutch angles, cockeyed compositions, wide-angle lenses, herky-jerky camerawork, and blown-out lighting, and that frenetic, over-the-top lensing. Gives such a perspective of the fractured state of mind. 
Big commentary about capitalism, environmentalism, masochism, and extremism. 
Now this movie lands with a more truth to it. It's vision is more prophetic and it's emotions and psychology match what we are facing today. Everything is dingy and dark with death lurking around every corner.
Willis and Pitt are tremendous with such a smart premise, a well-developed construct of the future, and uncertain fears of illusion vs reality. 
Such a sad ending too but it cleverly ties everything together.
For an intriguing pandemic film that remains delightfully sans pandemic, it's the best.

Personally, this was a tough film to finish - couldn't finish it in one sitting. First off - this movie has got to have one of the most misleading titles of all time; although of course that is most likely done on purpose, for the viewers to fixate on the 12 monkeys, then later on pull the rug during the last minutes of the movie. My favorite part has to be Brad Pitt's acting to bring his character to life. Psychological thrillers are my favorite genre but this falls a little flat in terms of executing the twists and turns I expect in a psychological thriller. Admittedly, the theme of a virus causing a dystopian world in the future kind of hits close to home while watching it in 2020, and gives it a more eery and dreary effect.
Its plot is a little convoluted and confusing, but its excellent performances, stylish visuals and surprising plot twists make it an undeniable sci-fi cult classic.
A really clever script makes this more than your run of the mill science fiction film.

On one hand I think the acting was excellent, but on the other a bit ropey. I'm not sure which and not sure why. I think this is to be left to the viewer to decide. 

"Twelve Monkeys" is 100% worth a watch and certainly wont disappoint a film lover.

Although it isn't even close to the brilliance of Brazil, 12 Monkeys is another example of the other side of Terry Gilliam. Early on, while watching every Gilliam film, I was frustrated with the fact that every movie he made seemed to try too hard to be another Python movie. Now, I think it's safe to say that I am officially out of that period. Rather, 12 Monkeys has shown light to the other side of Gilliam, which, in a lot of ways I prefer. This new side of Gilliam, though, has a very strong trend in all of his movies. Every one of them has a strong relation to mental institutions. Fisher King, Brazil, and now 12 Monkeys, all have very strong references to mental illness. In a lot of ways, that first act of 12 Monkeys in the mental institution is probably it's best. In those scenes, we start to recognize what kind of a character Bruce Willis is. On that note, I honestly haven't ever been a huge fan of Bruce Willis. In 12 Monkeys, he's mediocre at best. The real actor that shines in 12 Monkeys is Brad Pitt. He plays crazy incredibly well in the movie, personally, I think the performance was even Oscar-worthy. The next few beats in the story aren't quite as good. For the majority of the second act, 12 Monkeys takes on the role of a demented road trip. After that, it's mostly chaos. These final beats were fine, but I didn't think they quite held up to my expectations from how good everything plays out at the beginning. 12 Monkeys is incredibly relevant in the middle of the pandemic as well. I feel that if I had watched this movie a couple years earlier, I'd be like "woah, crazy, unbelievable, science fiction stuff." But, right now, a man coming back to the past seems like an average Tuesday afternoon. As for the time travel, often, time travel is handled quite well. However, I have never been bothered by time travel plot holes throughout my movie watching time. The only thing I found lacking with time travel, and with the rest of the movie, is the visual style. Gilliam has always been able to illustrate the strangeness of everything, however, it seems as if he didn't fully utilize that in 12 Monkeys. In fact, the visual style was really just bland, sometimes even unappealing, but that was far from often. Still, the movie offers a mystery that is compelling and unique enough to have a good time.
This shit slapppppssss!!!

A time-travel movie from Terry Gilliam is bound to be weird in a cool way, and 12 Monkeys proves that to be true. Bruce Willis leads this tale of a man sent back in time in order to stop a worldwide plague. Multiple viewings are required to catch all the twists, but this is an enjoyable ride. Perhaps Brad Pitt's greatest role.
The acting wasn't too bad from everyone, but the film made no sense and was a rather bizarre film. It wasn't very good.

Absolutely insane sci-fi concept.

Terry Gilliam's demented mind is a beautiful thing. His psychological sci-fi thriller 12 Monkeys (1995) is as bizarre as Gilliam gets as director with strange imagery and mental patients. Gilliam's direction is both dreamy to look at and muddled in a confusing mess. He switches things around on the audience so fast that I became unsure of what was even happening on screen several times. Thankfully, he's got such an expressive directorial style that you can still glean what is going on thanks to context clues and bits of dialogue. Terry Gilliam took the French short film La Jetee and made it his own with his uniquely off brand direction. Roger Pratt's cinematography looks sweet and memorable with dated parts of goofy angles and weird perspectives in other parts. 12 Monkeys is a blast, but an unnerving one.

Mick Audsley's editing is sort of the issue for me as he cuts around the time travel, so that you are disoriented and never quite sure what is happening. Unfortunately, 129 minutes of jumping around gets tiresome and makes the narrative confusing, especially with all of writers Janet Peoples and David Webb Peoples' cool plot twists. Astor Piazolla's suites are interpolated for parts of Paul Buckmaster's killer score, so much so that I'd say Astor composed the score for 12 Monkeys. It all sounds like passages from his legendary "Libertango" to me.

Jeffrey Beecroft's production design is so industrial and ugly for the future that 12 Monkeys looks cool and hideous, simultaneously. Julie Weiss and Eric H. Sandberg's costumes are playful spins on old sci-fi concepts as well as 1990's baggy clothes. It's fun to see Allen Weisinger's crazy make-up throughout 12 Monkeys too.

Bruce Willis is compelling as the lead. It's amazing how he would just take a beating for these old movies back when he actually tried acting. It's no The Sixth Sense or Unbreakable, but Willis is awesome in 12 Monkeys. He takes that hammy attitude from The Fifth Element and the man of action reacting to strangeness from the Die Hard franchise and blends them together into a cool protagonist named James Cole. He has great chemistry with the lovely Madeleine Stowe as Dr. Kathryn Railly. She's throughout and erratic as needed in a neat supporting actress role for her. 

Brad Pitt steals the show as the insane anarchist, animal lover, mental patient, revolutionary Jeffrey Goines. His crazy contacts, hand gestures, rambling dialogue, and wacky delivery are quite entertaining. Christopher Plummer is excellent as his genius father Dr. Goines. David Morse has a memorable cameo as Dr. Peters. Jon Seda is interesting as Willis' fellow inmate Jose. In all, 12 Monkeys is weird, but watchable.

When you watch a Gilliam movie you know you're watching a Gilliam movie, and I can appreciate that. Mix one part Kafkaesque, one part suffocating futurism, and combine those with American versions of British dialogue and you get pure Gilliam. Better than The Fisher King, but can't even touch Brazil, Twelve Monkeys grips you at parts and drops you at others. I swear, I had no idea it was about a virus that wipes out almost all of humanity, so I kinda freaked myself out there. Bruce Willis as James Cole and Madeleine Stowe as Dr. Kathryn Railly had great chemistry with a nice arch but didn't need them to fall in love. Dr. Railly is a smart, cunning character throughout, but she's upset that Cole kills the man who is literally undoing his belt to rape her? Come on. All that being said, Brad Pitt as the mentally-ill, enviro-terrorist, Jeffrey Goines, steals the show every time he's on-screen, we just needed more of it. Reviewed 11.25.18   Terry Gilliam, hodge-podge or visionary director depending on the critic, delivers perhaps his most cohesive film.  Besides an ending that should have been cut one scene short, the misdirects are well-placed.  They leave the viewer a bit disjointed, but that's obviously the intended effect.  Both to mimic the emotional state of James Cole (Bruce Willis), and to successfully disguise the rabbit in hand.  

The pieces are right in front of you, yet the resolution is still a surprise, and a well-earned one at that.  And even with characters that are devoid of functional human connections, the finale manages a deeply sentimental resolution to the love story.  It is quite the balancing act, and Gilliam delivers a true original.  Like it or not, you won't question that it's different.

For me, this was the movie that showed Brad Pitt had true acting chops.  No long flowing hair machismo in this one.  He let his freak flag fly, and an all-time great career took flight.  The Academy took notice too, with his first nomination.  

The film's combination of off-kilter humor and sci-fi noir make for interesting bedfellows.  It captures a legendary director at his best, a Hollywood star at his peak, and another launching his eclectic path.  Edgy humor, a quirky love story, a weird vibe...oh the 90's.

This is now right on my list of favourite movies.

Time travel is such an interesting topic, and will forever be an interesting topic. Time itself is such an elusive thing.

That being said, this movie is truly genius. Everything from the way the story unfolds, to the way the ideas are presented (in true Gilliam fashion), and even to the way Gilliam uses time travel to tell a very captivating and relevant story.

We all wish in some ways that we could go back in time to alter the future. What makes this movie so interesting is that it negates this theory. It shows us that we can't go back in time to alter the future. But we can go back to learn something to take into the future. This itself is such a brilliant way of looking at things and sort of a realistic approach to life. I'll find myself looking towards my past to learn about something to take with into the future and implement it into my life. Mistakes, experiences that have happened, it's all important in the future and even more so in the now. 

You see, this is what movies should do. Movies should make us think. They should make us reach deep down inside of ourselves and make us question a lot of things about life and make us introspect on our lives and life itself. What if time travel really existed? What if people from the past living in the present right now? What if life itself is just one big game and we should be playing it as such, like Scrabble or Monopoly? I guess we'll never know until we pass on to another life.

Overall, a brilliant movie with striking visuals and an amazing storyline to boot. Will definitely watch it again.

*On a side note, I wish Brad Pitt did more nutty roles.*

A deadly virus wipes out almost all of humanity in 1996, forcing remaining survivors to live underground. A mysterious group known as the Army of the Twelve Monkeys is believed to be behind the virus. In 2035, James Cole (Bruce Willis) is a prisoner living in a subterranean shelter beneath the ruins of Philadelphia. Cole is selected for a mission, where he is trained and sent back in time to collect information on the virus in order to help scientists develop a cure. Meanwhile, Cole is troubled by recurring dreams involving a foot chase and an airport shooting. Cole arrives in Baltimore in 1990, not 1996 as planned. He is arrested, then hospitalized in a mental institution on the diagnosis of Dr. Kathryn Railly (Madeleine Stowe). There he encounters Jeffrey Goines (Brad Pitt), a fellow mental patient with fanatical views. After an escape attempt, Cole is locked in a cell, but soon disappears, returning to the future. Back in his own time, Cole is interviewed by the scientists, who play a distorted voicemail message which discloses the location of the Army of the Twelve Monkeys and asserts their association with the virus. He is also shown photos of numerous people suspected of being involved, including Goines. He is given a second chance to go back in time, but another error results in him arriving at a battlefield of World War I. He is wounded in the leg and then suddenly sent to 1996. In 1996, Railly gives a lecture about the Cassandra complex to a group of scientists. At the post-lecture book signing, Dr. Peters (David Morse) questions her about mankind's sustainability on earth and points out that humanity's gradual destruction of the environment may be the real lunacy. Cole arrives at the venue after seeing flyers publicizing it, and when Railly departs, he kidnaps her and forces her to take him to Philadelphia. They learn that Goines is the founder of the Army of the Twelve Monkeys, and set out in search of him. When they confront him, however, Goines denies any involvement with the virus and says that wiping out humanity was Cole's idea at the asylum in 1990. Cole convinces himself that he is insane, but Railly confronts him with evidence of his time travel. They decide to spend their remaining time together in the Florida Keys before the onset of the plague. On their way to the airport, they learn that the Army of the Twelve Monkeys was not the source of the epidemic; the group's major act of protest is releasing animals from a zoo and placing Goines' Nobel Prize winning virologist father (Christopher Plummer) in an animal cage...

Roger Ebert observed 12 Monkeys' depiction of the future, finding similarities with Blade Runner (1982; also scripted by David Peoples) and Brazil (1985; also directed by Terry Gilliam). "The film is a celebration of madness and doom, with a hero who tries to prevail against the chaos of his condition, and is inadequate", Ebert wrote. "This vision is a cold, dark, damp one, and even the romance between Willis and Stowe feels desperate rather than joyous. All of this is done very well, and the more you know about movies (especially the technical side), the more you're likely to admire it. And as entertainment, it appeals more to the mind than to the senses." Desson Thomson of The Washington Post praised the art direction and set design. "Willis and Pitts's performances, Gilliam's atmospherics and an exhilarating momentum easily outweigh such trifling flaws in the script", Thomson reasoned. Peter Travers from Rolling Stone magazine cited the film's success on Gilliam's direction and Willis' performance. Internet reviewer James Berardinelli believed the filmmakers took an intelligent and creative motive for the time travel subplot. Rather than being sent to change the past, James Cole is instead observing it to make a better future. Richard Corliss of Time magazine felt the film's time travel aspect and apocalyptic depiction of a bleaker future were clichés. "In its frantic mix of chaos, carnage and zoo animals, 12 Monkeys is Jumanji for adults", Corliss wrote. 

Terry Gilliam is a director who never have and nor will take the easy way. I respect him for that. I reckon every movie he has been involved in has been a chaotic mess with various results. I reckon he needs that sort of project and environment to be able to deliver his best. However, he doesn´t always succeed. With "Twelve Monkeys" Gilliam moves in wellknown territories. The vibe and setting is close to "Brazil" but with a time travel setting. A sort of mix of "Donnie Darko" and "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" with a sci-fi vibe and a nod to how science and biological holocausts can collapse our planet. "Twelve Monkeys" is unique and original in many ways, and the storyline manages to keep the viewer on the right track throughout the movie despite a quite dynamic and fluctuant plot with present and future settings. Gilliam pushes the idea that one can't change the past and there´s a thin line between sanity and madness. The narrative is thought-provoking and I do enjoy that. When re-seeing it today Bruce Willis does Bruce Willis, while Brad Pitt steals most scenes as the warped Jeffrey Goines. What I also noticed is that the film is tainted by the 90s way of making films, lot of close ups and tilted angles. "Twelve Monkeys" is as said unique, but it didn´t create the same impact on me when re-seeing it as it did in 1995. Trivia: "Twelve Monkeys" is inspired by the French short film "La Jetée" (1962); as in "La Jetée", characters are haunted by the image of their own death. After Universal Studios acquired the rights to remake "La Jetée" as a full-length film, David and Janet Peoples were hired to write the script. Under Gilliam's direction, Universal granted the filmmakers a $29.5 million budget and filming lasted from February to May 1995. The film was shot mostly in Philadelphia and Baltimore where the story was set. The film was released to critical praise and grossed $168 million worldwide. Pitt was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor and won a Golden Globe for his performance. The film also won and was nominated for various categories at the Saturn Awards.

A busy film designed to make you think whilst also developing the future. Twelve Monkeys is certainly ahead of its time and the influence can be seen on mind bending films today. The usual Gilliam techniques are used on a script that potentially was designed for a very different vision however it is Gilliam's uniqueness that makes this film stand out, let alone the fact that the cast members wanted to work with him whatever the cost. In most cases that was for very little. Gilliam's style combined with the solid a-list cast and performances make the potentially messy plot become overlooked. The absurdity of the narrative makes for intrigue and works with the time-jumping story telling. In hindsight it is definitely the perfect script for a director such as Gilliam. The score can feel out of place, the emotional development of the two leads relationship doesn't feel deep enough and there is a slight lull in the middle however this is a film that must be seen to see classy performances from actors at the start of long careers and a narrative that leaves questions open for you to answer yourself on either a second viewing or in discussion down the local.

Most time travel stories are hard to understand but this one just doesn't give the viewer any chance of understanding for a long time, We are forced into being spoon fed the plot in small doses and none of it makes much sense for a long time or fits into what's happening on screen at the time, Plus the very misleading name of the film will only be a giant middle finger to people trying to make sense of the plot, Having said that it makes the crazy story more exciting it's also very unpredictable, All the cast were great but I did enjoy Brad Pitts character more than any, It had a great ending that worked well with the dark mood of the film, It won't appeal to many but people that will watch it and can understand it will love it.
Super trippy and effective... but goes on too long and I didn't like that they resolved the whole thing, I would've rather it be left up in the air. Still fantastic.
Very interesting and we'll written story. Although it is 20 years old, it still holds up today.  I would watch this again

12 monkeys is an intense mind numbing intelligent time-travel sci-fi movie with a fantastic cast. This time travelling role was, in my opinion, the best film role for Bruce Willis yet because it combined brains with brawn. While the goal of Bruce Willis was to travel back in time to change destiny by preventing the worst biological terrorism ever that wiped out 5 billion people, the important message in the film was ultimately that destiny and hence history cannot be changed. A fact we must recognize in our real world also. Can anyone change what our God almighty, has already fixed even before the foundation of the world? Our time traveller, Bruce (James Cole) attempted exactly this foolish endeavor with predictable failure. He got caught up in the never ending looping of time this has always been part of history already.  Like a broken record, he loops back and forward in time endlessly according to the written unchanging script of life but impossible to change one single bit of history.  The filmed climaxed for one brief tragic moment when the seven-year-old James Cole would witness the 45-year-old James Cole being gunned down, which became the never-ending nightmares of the seven-year old James Cole. He would of course return to this part of his history in furue.  The rest of the cast was nothing but magnificent. The damsel in distress Madeleine Stowe and the brilliant rising young star Brad Pitt, who played the loony character to perfection. A worthy match for Jack Nicholson's iconic performance in 'One flew over the cuckoo's nest' indeed.

By the same token that we are all time travelers if any of us are there is no past that is not present & therefore  if mutable we can never be aware of that which we take back from existence in our constant reenaction of infinite possibilty. We would therefore all be time travelers but never aware of that in any present we can now inhabit.

But this movie isn't about time travel. That's just a tool to maintain control.

12 Monkeys is a unique and well made science fiction film. The cast is great, Brad Pitt is excellent in an underutilized supporting role. The story is grim and intense, making for a really interesting story. The writing is very good, and the costume/production design are great. The overall concept is engaging at first, but loses its way towards the middle. It feels like the movie is holding us back from looking into the bigger ideas promised from the start. The ending brings the jumbled time paradoxes to a surprising and extremely clever finale. The tone and direction of this movie are solid, and there are many interesting ideas mixed with great performances. Twelve Monkeys gets 4/5 stars (A-).
While the plot and themes may puzzle some people, 12 Monkeys is exceptional for it’s performances from Bruce Willis and Brad Pitt plus a really reasonably real concept of a virus killing mankind

The consensus says the plot's a jumble - and that is the best part of the movie. Un-jumbling it adds to the charm of the movie.
And then, you have semi-comic, melancholic background score to create an even more riveting environment. The only people who will not like this are those who don't want to think through the movie, and expect to be fed all info.
Must watch!!
Very 90s. Exaggerated acting. One dimensional characters.  Mediocre dialogue. Plot holes. Watchable.

This is one of those films that leave you feeling like something's not quite being said; led by an amazing performance from Bruce Willis, the story is a bit surreal and quite interesting. I would recommend this if you're into sci-fi or not-so-common scripts.
Despite its frustratingly disappointing ending, "Twelve Monkeys" still holds itself up with some solid twists and aesthetic brilliance all throughout.
The actors are amazing in this film especially Brad Pitt. It also looks great but the plot is haphazard and it's kind of confusing at times.
dramatic, disturbing, beautifully directed and excellent performance from Pitt. It is one of the futuristic films having a good psychological content that makes it spectacular
Brad Pitt is the absolute man!
Interesting twists & a clever story along with a dashing performance from Brad Pitt makes 12 Monkeys a great watch. Probably the best work of Terry Gilliam.
It's a ways out there but this quirky(being kind)thriller is more than worth the trip.

A film I saw when it came out and found great at the time. Seeing it again, it is still pretty good except for some effects. Bruce Willis plays the uncertain hero very well. Madeleine Stowe the shaken psychiatrist also. Some themes of the films really are hitting home. The crazy dangerous suspects, inoffensive mostly. The way the future wants to change itself by affecting the past but seems to slip by unscathed. The ambiguity between dream, reality, insanity. What seems insane is less so than what seems real at times. The most flagrant flaw I saw was in slow motion, when the hero get shot at the airport. The themes and the story are what makes this film so endearing. And the confused hero. I understand the ending as follows: 1- the investigator from the future finally catch up the bad guy and prevents the apocalypse; 2- same but she can't prevent the apocalypse, only learns more about the virus to be able to resolve the issue in the future. This also resolves the issue of time-impossibility. 3- the woman is in the present beside the bad guy and just happens to become a survivor investigating in the future, unknowingly being next to what she was looking for. 
According to the dvd extras, I vote 2- the most likely ending. 
Great film. I see that it is coming back in tv serial now.

Well thought out, though still possessed of some issues, 12 Monkeys is a film unlike anything else Terry Gillam has done before or since, a neat sci-fi that endears itself to almost all who watch it (myself included), regardless of what could be said about it objectively.
What the fudge is wrong with Terry Gilliam?

Time travel mindfuck based on the French 'film' Le Jete is probably Terry Gilliam's most mainstream film and ranks among one of Bruce Willis's biggest departure from his typical roles.

Channeling the temporal mechanics of Time Bandits, the societal decay of Brazil and the doomed madman quest of the Fisher King, 12 Monkeys proves itself as the rare remake that leaves the original behind. Once again Gilliam explores the theme of madness, quests, and the reactions from society and individuals. He cleverly switches near film's end, juxtaposing the believer/non believer role among Willis and Madeline Stowe, making for necessary jolt to the last third of the film.
Spectacular! Sad and funny, mad and brilliant, it's everything and its opposite. Really really well made.

This movie is an interesting sci-movie and stars Bruce Willis and Brad Pitt and Pitt was incredible in this movie, he played such a funny and interesting character. The plot I feel is a bit of a mess, this movie is the sort of movie that has very interesting characters and story but just doesn't nail the execution. The character of the female Dr in my opinion added nothing to the story.This is still a solid movie to watch and I would recommend it to sci-fi movie fans.

Loved this movie. The whole concept of it was really awesome. I thought the main cast did a great job. Willis didn't seem like his normal self. He really gave it his all and got 100% into it. The time travel scenes were done well. The future set pieces also looked really cool. Post apocalyptic and very rundown textures were a great idea for the future scenes. Brad Pitt in the mental hospital was awesome. He just becomes a total wack job!
Interesting film, but the plot does get a bit messy. Twist is kind of predictable, but the ending does leave you thinking about the aftermath, which is kinda nice.
Gilliam's best picture by far.

I am not a Bruce Willis fan though through no fault of my own I have seen most of his films. Of these only "The Fifth Element" and this are worth watching.

Terry Gilliam doesn't let his visual style overwhelm the story and lets the acting talent of Stowe and Willis carry the film forward. i even came away with some respect for Brad Pitt as a actor and not just a Hollywood "Pretty Boy".

Based on the short french film La Jetée, Terry Gilliam (the american from Monty Python) uses swirling camera movement and meticulous attention to detail to draw us into this world. The screen is littered with with drooling mental patients covered in garbage in rotting back alleys. He does a great job of making us doubt Cole as an unreliable protagonist giving us hints that it'll all unravel like 6th Sense (Willis loves numbers and twists). On top of the set-design Gilliam mixes in a great  accordion theme for additional atmosphere within the fragile psyche. 
Bruce Willis does a solid job of carrying the narrative, and Madeleine Stowe is memorably compassionate, but all the focus will be on 90's sex-symbol Brad Pitt's Oscar nominated turn as a crazy Jeffery Goines and deservedly so. Pitt's best roles are his weirdos, and he should play them more often.
In more recent news, the SYFY channel now has a new 12 Monkeys show that just debuted. If it turns out to be anywhere near as good as the movie I'd say it'll be a show worth investing in. While the plot can be murkily confusing, this is a twistedly satisfying film and a sci-fi classic.
Flawed but well acted and entertaining enough to be worth the watch.

I haven't seen that one in a long time and I was in the mood for a dystopia.. to see a film that ends with the end of the world. I found myself appreciating Gilliam's style even more now that I've seen all the Monty Python's work and understood his role in the group. I thought Brad Pitt's acting was over-the-top

This movie is all over the place. Performances I was surprised by that eventually degenerated halfway through and a plot that feels all over the place in terms of writing and execution. I liked it but, dont find it great. Ended it with a headache. It has a great beginning though and often leaves you contemplating if it was worth it.
Fantastic performances from Bruce Willis and Brad Pitt with an interesting plot, typical Terry Gilliam, which made it interesting. It took me a while to get around to watching this but I enjoyed it.
A sci-fi with more heart and brains than a number of its peers with one of Bruce Willis' best performances to date. Full review later.

Simply mind-blowing movie. What if we are living in the past and the future already happened? Or is the whole world just in your head? And are the "crazy" people really crazy or just what society thinks crazy is like? It leaves you thinking and surely not forgetting this experience.
you either really love Terry Gilliam movies, or you don't.  I happened to thoroughly enjoy this one.

The look and tone are completely bizarre, but the plot is pretty straight forward.  It's a little slow in the beginning but it does present a few interesting sci-fi ideas.  Plus, the film has several surprises and twists that should be enjoyable for those who have never seen it before.
My favourite Terry Gilliam movie by far. A brilliantly and cleverly made sci-fi talking about self-fulfilled prophecy and time travel.

Psychology and time travelling entwined in this twisted science fiction masterpiece. 12 Monkeys is about a plague which wiped up nearly all of the populations on the planet, people had to retreat underground to survive. The remaining few scientists were experimenting with time travel devices and used convicts as subjects. James Cole was chosen to go back in time to retrieve information regarding the plague in order to alter the history. A series of misfortune ensured with the faulty device, eventually Cole managed to convince a psychiatrist to help him stop the plague, will they be able to save the human race?

12 monkeys combined the idea of time travel with psychological dissocation of the mind where the reality became a delusion. The theme is the exploration of Cassandra syndrome, named after the Greek princess who was able to have premonition but unable to convince anyone to prevent the prophecy from happening. 

The acting was superb from all the main characters. Pitt played a mentally disturbed eco terrorist and played it so well. Willies' performance was incredibly excellent. The writing was fantastic, I love the dystopian version of the Los Angeles where crime and poverty ruled the city. The idiotic terrorists were depicted well too.

The cinematography was excellent too, I love the unusual angles typically found in horror film but used in a way to induce psychological displeasure. The sepia tone made the atmosphere all the more pessimistic. The cyberpunk set design was another brilliant addition to further propagate uncertainty and fear.

12 monkeys is a milestone of the American science fiction cinema.
While this film was entertaining and had a good cast, I've seen better apocalyptic sci-fi films.
Entertaining but it's premise is severely flawed. Another time paradox movie.

Gripping performances and compelling storytelling makes this not only one of the best time travel films but one of the best films period. 
Grade: A
Still my favorite Brad Pitt performance and one of the most original time-travel movies. The visuals are very distinct and give the movie an overall quality feel

One of the more creative time traveling movies that deals with bureaucratic incompetence, paranoia, and mindf**ks galore. It is a film that makes you second guess your sanity halfway through and hopes that indeed you are nuts.
A dark and gritty sci-fi thriller, 12 Monkeys stands apart from other sci-fi films, due to its unique and twisted concept on the future of mankind.

Dark, twisted and often head scratching, Gilliam's time travel tale is a mesmerizing experience, even if it doesn't quite stack up to the uniqueness of 'Brazil'. That's not to dismiss three solid main performances or the unmistakably Gilliam visuals brimming with wacky details.
Just an all around awesome movie...! Very well made

Not some monkey business.

 12 Monkeys is a fine time-travel based sci-fi movies. Its smart and filled with outstanding performances by Bruce Willis as lead and Brad Pitt in supporting role. James Cole(Bruce Willis) gets sent back in time to save humanity from an apocalypse set up by a unknown virus infestation. It begins nicely but soon loses focus. But its Brad Pitt playing a lunatic who saves the day in the asylum where Willis ends up after being sent into the past.This is one of the best performace he has given till date.
 The best thing about the movie is that it generates suspense in the minds of the viewers whether it is time travel or just mindgames of Cole.The script is neat focusing on variety of things that happen in this corporate system. Also another positive of the film is the character played by the lovely Madeleine Stowe which is of Cole's psychiatrist. She adds the required charm in this dark time-travel loop. 
 The ending is marvellous and really fits perfectly for the questions raised by the time-travel in the movie.I would have liked it more if it had on developed more interesting thoughts in the middle rather than using the same ideas. Anyways its worth a watch for all sci-fi fans.

RATING: [3.5/5]
Came for the monkeys, stayed for Bruce Willis.

The craziness of Terry Gilliam can be seen throughout the movie, and coupled with a great performance by Brad Pitt (one of his best), makes this film worth of a viewing. But the story ultimately lacks clear direction and fall into mundane plotlines.  I used to think more of this film, but was letdown by a recent viewing as being not as good as I remembered. I would have liked to have seen it go further and cookier than it does.
Zero Theorem seems like an even worse film after seeing how good Twelve Monkeys is.
I'm not saying it's bad, but it's long, very confusing, but this is one of Pitt's best acting. Willis is good too. But the ending is just awful.
Pitt is unstoppable, this is the 4th movie with him as a main character with a 5 stars by my part, awesome, insame, maniatic, memorable.
One of the best movies ever.
A really smart plot and the great performances make this film a sci-fi masterpiece.

"12 Monkeys" is without a doubt one of the most bizarre, intriguing movies ever made. It made me later on in life realize Terry Gilliam and in my opinion Brad Pitt gives the best performance of his career, he nearly steals the show.

This is a really interesting movie that got better as it went along. You'll definitely be confused for the first little bit - I sure was. But more and more gets explained and it really all comes together very nicely at the end as stuff starts to make more and more sense. Brad Pitt is of course great as the crazy villain. But Willis isn't to be ignored, as he is also great as the damaged, violent Cole who is struggling to believe what is real and what he should even do. A very under appreciated film. Definitely watch this one, if you like complex plot, sci-fi and time travel.

What an outstanding piece of science fiction. I love this film and reckon a rewatch will bolster my understanding of the material. Well that's what the film's about really, seeing the same thing over and over but noticing something different every time, due to how you change and grow.
Strong and convincing portrayals of psychosis help set the unstable groundwork for a twisted, sharp satire.

I cannot deny that I am a DIE HARD Willis fan for no other reason than he's methodically earned every ounce of. Y respect and fandom from his first days on MOONLIGHTING when I was 15 to his current perfection in RED II. Twelve monkeys may easily be one of he best movies ever made, best stories ever told, it's absolute immaculate perfection exceeded only by the sublime energy created by the madman and his psychiatrist as they race to undo history only to discover they have already sealed its fate and the path that leads them to first attempt to undo it at all...the great circle that LOOPER later tries to resell but with much less  impeccable absolutes. Pitts madness is awesome to watch, Gillian's character amusing and the story unravels like life itself, messy and unspeakable. Love this movie and everything about it.
A bit too long and a bit too jumbled but the performances and the ambition of this add up to solid film, albeit one that hasn't quite stood the time test
One of the craziest time-travel/Sci-Fi films that I have ever seen.
Hard to see, getting old, but still full of energy

Science fiction thriller featuring Bruce Willis, Brad Pitt, Madeleine Stowe and a young Christopher Merloni. Time-travel, suspense & a bit of apocalyptic romance, mostly taking place in Philadelphia with some good shots of the city (e.g. City Hall with a lion on top, giraffes & elephants running around the city).

The one Terry Gilliam film I saw in theaters is, coincidentally, my favorite. I'm naturally inclined to enjoy 12 Monkeys because time travel is easily my favorite plot device for a film. I love how Bruce Willis' actions each time he travels back seems to have a ripple effect for each other time he goes, and yet he is so adamant that nothing he does can change the future because the past has already happened. It did seem a bit inconsistent what information was making it to the future, but the authority figures in the future were ambiguous enough that it didn't really matter because they could just be holding back information. What makes 12 Monkeys more interesting than most movies of this kind is the fact that we are given enough evidence to believe that the time travel might not actually be happening. We are led down a psychological path that calls us to question everything we're being shown. Is James Cole a reliable witness for anything? I wish Gilliam had stuck with his instincts and left off the lines in the opening, because they sell the audience completely on the time travel aspect and force the movie to work harder to sell the fact that it is possible none of the future scenes are real.

The underground future world is typical Gilliam craziness. It looks like a miserable place to live, and makes it easy to see why Cole would become enamored with the past so quickly. I love the set of the asylum as well, because it feels uncomfortable, and unwelcoming. The 2 big performances in this movie are simply amazing. Bruce Willis is at the top of his game, as he wanders back-and-forth between sane and crazy. I love the fact that I'm never really sure whether he is going to lose it and kill someone, or not. Brad Pitt is absolutely perfect in 12 Monkeys. He is completely unhinged, and totally convincing as Jeffrey Goines to the point where I almost don't see Brad Pitt because he disappears into the role. When he starts ranting in that fast-paced way, I keep expecting that I'll lose track of what he is saying, and yet he articulates extremely well. 12 Monkeys has a nice ending that isn't quite a twist, but works perfectly. There are other movies that I like more that involve time travel, but this is certainly near the top of the list. It is one that I think everyone should experience, even if it's just for the great acting.
Way awesome, and possibly Brad Pitt's best performance...

One of the modern-day greatest cautionary tales present by one of today's finest surrealism thinkers. Such a super high-caliber cast which meets a super-duper script and helmed by an unsurpassable director makes 12 Monkeys a true masterpiece.
Absolutely incredible movie, probably my fave Brad Pitt film.
Time travel wrap-up is a cliché nowadays.

A fascinating "time travel" film that does well to extrapolate upon the ideas presented in "La Jette".
Not only does Brad Pitt play a very convincing crazy person (even before "Fight Club"), but Bruce Willis maintains his sci-fi credibility with his role in this film.
Having also loved Gilliam's "Brazil", I think I might have to find more of his films, because I really like his style.

Enthralling, original, and deeply entertaining, 12 Monkeys pulls you through hoops of time and plot to present one of the best sci-fi/thrillers of the '90s. Outstanding performances by Brad Pitt and Bruce Willis excel 12 Monkeys past the somewhat confusing plot. Amazingly entertaining direction from Terry Gilliam.

Remember the time when we used to like Bruce Willis. The film is about a convict is sent back in time by a group of scientists in hopes of learning how to stop the disease. The acting in this movie was brilliant, Brad Pitt and Bruce Willis and everybody else did a fine job in they roles. The movie makes you feel dirty and unclean inside which is a good thing in the movie because the film is trying to get across how dark the world is.

Plot twists fly out in all sorts of directions and occasionally threaten the sanity of Terry Gilliam's Twelve Monkeys, but it thankfully culminates with a satisfying bite, making it an interesting and unique sci-fi tale, with excellent performances all round.
An awesome film set in the future 2035 where life on earth is impossible, except for underground. It involves time travel and a fantastic twist ending that you will not see coming.
Brilliant films with amazing actors
Twelve monkeys is just enough. This is a great movie.
You won't want to watch it after it's over, you'll need to.
Didn't understand anything that went on in this movie.
Something weird, something odd, and something sinister all wrapped up in a bow and served up with Bruce Willis and Brad Pitt

My God, you want to talk about movies that are easily confusing and throw you for a loop at every turn? And that's coming from someone who is usually used to these things in the movies he watches. However, I enjoy films that make you think, such as 12 Monkeys did. 

12 Monkeys consists of your general "Earth and humanity have been decimated from a plague" post-apocalyptic premise; except for the fact that time travel is technologically feasible in this dystopian future. Bruce Willis is a convict who strikes a bargain to travel back in time and prevent the virus outbreak, thus reducing his sentence. Overall, the plot would seem (at first glance) to contain a feeling of "been there, done that". That's when the plot-twists start coming in. Boy, let me tell you, they threw me for a loop over and over again.
So beautifully deceptive. A little bit of 90s cheese but just a brilliant story and twist.
This movie is fantastic! Brad Pitt does such an amazing job. He brings his character to life, and the plot is just great.
Not sure how I feel about this... might need to watch it again

One of those cases where the writers had a good beginning and a good ending but didn't know how to effectively tie it together. 'Twelve Monkeys' is a jumble of time travel and mostly boring encounters before then reaching a semi-intelligent ending which links well with the first scene. Got the feeling that the movie didn't know what to do for the main segment and so just dilly-dallies until it can reveal the plot twists near the end. Brad Pitt won the golden globe and nominated for an Oscar for his role as the extremely insane, animal rights activist and rightfully so since his are the only scenes which will make you perk up. Unfortunately, I do not feel it is a solid enough reason to watch this. 

'Twelve Monkeys' was suppose to be an entertaining beginning to my time travel back to highly rated films of the 90s. If it continues in this fashion then I may have to return to the present sooner than expected.

Ah, I just love a good non-linear film, and 12 Monkeys satisfies that craving to the fullest. Bruce Willis is unsettling and crazy in all the right ways, and Brad Pitt is neurotic in all the best ways. There's no fairytale world in this movie; just a great big messed up fantasy. To decipher what's real, what's fake, what's in the past, what's in the future could take forever, in fact, it might even be impossible. This is the great mystery of this film.

This one is a mind fucker. One cannot help but be impressed by such amazing performances for the leading trio perfectly surpassing some screenplay flaws when it comes to overcomplicating. More simply, too many ropes are tied up for the viewers to untie.

It is a narrative mess and layered with superficiality, but the amazing technical skill behind the camera and the acting skill on camera, combined with its general quirkiness, make it a engrossing piece of cinema.
This movie's phenomenal acting and highly intelligent plot make for a thrilling and slightly disturbing ride.
Trust me, its too overrated!
Great science fiction by Terry Gilliam. It's not as fine as "Brazil" but it earned Brad Pitt his well-deserved first Oscar nomination.

A jumble plot , poor story telling,Unprecedented plot twists keeps this move that runs 2 hr 18 mins a BIG NO even with the powerful star casting. Very messy and undeniably confusing in an uninteresting way.Boredom Sci Fi movie that does not make any sense.

This is a film that tricks you into thinking it's a jumble of surreal nonsense, but when you dig deeper you find exciting plot twists, brilliant performances by a strong cast, incredible writing, and of course the very askew, astoundingly original touch of the great Terry Gilliam.
Really good. 8.3/10. B+.

"I am mentally divergent, in that I am escaping certain unnamed realities that plague my life here. When I stop going there, I will be well. Are you also divergent, friend?"

That is the question that the audience has to ask itself during this sci-fi mentally ill time traveling futuristic movie. Is the lead character mentally ill or is he really on a mission traveling through time in order to find a cure to a deadly virus that has wiped off nearly all the population and forced the few survivors to live underground? Director Terry Gilliam has created a memorable sci-fi flick that like all time traveling films has a few in-congruencies but still manages to hold the audience's attention. Gilliam is better known for his work in Monty Python, but he's also directed different types of genre films like The Fisher King (dramedy), Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (adventure), and The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus (Fantasy). He has a pretty respectable filmography as a director, although I still think he did his best work in the 90's. This film has a strong screenplay, but it will be remembered for the strong performances from Bruce Willis and Brad Pitt. Twelve Monkeys is a dark futuristic film similar in some ways to Blade Runner although it kind of diverges all over the place with so many ideas. This is an inventive film but I don't know how many ideas were taken from Chris Marker's 1962 short film, La jetee, which inspired this movie. The screenplay was adapted by David Webb Peoples (Blade Runner, Unforgiven) and Janet Peoples. His influence from Blade Runner seems to be mixed in the screenplay here as well. This is a very fun sci-fi film although full of really weird moments.

The film takes place sometime in the future after a deadly virus wiped out over 5 billion people and the few survivors were forced to live underground. James Cole (Bruce Willis) is a convict who is sent by a group of scientists to the past in order to gather information about the virus. The scientists want to study the virus so they can create a cure and live in the outside world once again. Cole is mistakenly sent to 1990 instead of 1996 which was the year in which the virus began spreading, and he ends up in a mental hospital after attacking several police officers. At the mental hospital he is treated by Dr. Railly (Madeleine Stowe) and he also meets another patient named Jeffrey Goines (Brad Pitt) who happens to be the son of a famous scientist (Christopher Plummer). Cole at first begins to search desperately for the "Army of the Twelve Monkeys" because they are believed to be the group responsible for spreading the virus, but later he begins to question himself and believe that he might actually be insane himself. This is a puzzle that he will have to piece together with the help of Railly. 

This is the puzzle that Gilliam invites the audience to solve along the way and keeps us guessing as the plot unfolds before our eyes. I'm not a huge fan of futuristic films, but Gilliam's vision here is pretty hypnotic and poetic. Most of the film actually takes place in the past, but there are several elements introduced that keep us guessing what will happen next. There were a few stand out scenes like the one in which Cole and Railly are at a movie theater and begin commenting on how despite having seen the movie before the perception of it changes every time, similar to what is happening with Cole through his time traveling. Does his presence in the past change things in the future? Can he find the virus on time in order to save the people in the future? These are a few questions that the film raises. The more you think about things the more flaws you will find, but that doesn't take away anything from this sci-fi film. I really liked Brad Pitt's performance here for which he received an Academy nomination, although he lost to Kevin Spacey (The Usual Suspects). The film runs a bit long, but it never ceases to entertain.

Between the original ideas and technical perfection, there would seem to be little room for performances but Pitt and Willis fill that space nicely. Specifically, for Willis this is one of his more emotionally developed roles in all his career. If there is a flaw with this film, it's the confusing inconsistencies it carries within the plot, which at times become too apparent to ignore.

This film lacked any and all sentiment. I didn't care for any of the characters. Not one of them had a shred of interesting points or personality (not including Brad Pitt's character, Jeffery). "Mind-blowing plot twists," I think not. Mind remains successfully un-blown.

This movie dragged. And dragged. And... dragged... and I felt that the psychiatrist's role in the story could have been omitted and it would have told the exact same plot without fail. Her character had no point other than to scream and snivel every moment she was on screen, and whatever "romance" was supposed to be going on between her and the protagonist was lacking in any emotion, as well as significance. In every scene featuring this "romance," it didn't matter, because it had nothing to do with anything. I didn't once feel that these two could ever actually be in love. They were just both so unlikeable.

Brad Pitt's performance, on the other hand, was by far the only entertaining aspect of the otherwise snooze-worthy film. His zany, crooked-eyed psychopath may have well been the only character worth watching.

There's a lot to be said about those who tackle the concept of time travel films, and needless to say, it's not a good route to take when creating a movie. Every time travel movie has gaping plot holes that make it impossible to enjoy for someone like me. When a movie ends with me seeing how it couldn't have possibly happened (even from a fictional standpoint), it's characterized as bad to me.

Lastly, I have no idea what this movie was trying to accomplish, nor what it was trying to tell people. Was it saying time travel was good? Bad? That Eco-terrorists will one day rule or destroy the planet? It was just a flimsy excuse for a poorly done romantic drama involving a doctor and patient, with a very implausible time travel twist. And it was worse than I was expecting.

One of the better Sci-Fi psychological thrillers I've seen (Coming from someone who loves these type of films). Twelve Monkeys is a hard movie to describe, because it's an incredibly complex movie that can be occasionally hard to follow. It is a film that constantly questions time, memory, humanity, and (most importantly) sanity. The three main actors - Willis, Pitt, and Madeleine Stowe - all do a great job, though it is Bruce Willis (the film's lead) who really stands out. The whole time we must question his sanity because he's not even sure if he's sane. The film is filled with great twists and, though it is a bit crazy, I actually rather enjoyed the insanity and confusion that it likes to live in. Worth a watch if you like sci-fi and psychological thrillers, though some aspects of the film (namely its visuals) are a bit dated and might turn some away.

An iconic film and one of the best science fiction movies that lives up that lives up to its title, about nightmares, time travel, death, and the future of mankind. James Cole (Bruce Willis) is a prisoner living in a future where most of the human race has been wiped out by a contagion, and a team of scientists desperately use prisoners like Cole to find the source of the disease. Cole, who has been having ominous nightmares since his childhood, is chosen by the scientists to go back in time before the contagion to find out where it came from. While the performances are a little over the top and the story's confusing at times, Twelve Monkeys is a complex, intriguing, and surprisingly bleak film, especially by a member of Monty Python.

"Back to the Future Goes to Hell" may be a worthy title and adequate description. This is a fine film in many respects but its inability to choose between serious and silly is just too much to overcome. The music is often times inappropriate as it reflects an attempt to infuse goofiness into what would otherwise be incredible moments of consequence. Brad Pitt is serviceable in his role but any good comedian could have pulled off the same performance. Bruce Willis is awesome and really was the saving grace as far as I was concerned. The fact is, time travel films spend a lot of time justifying themselves. They have to explain the nuances to the audience many of whom grow weary of its deployment. Don't be fooled into thinking that time travel narratives were first being explored, they were not. Stories that work within strict confines like "Memento" or "The Unforgiven" make for better stories.
